docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: FROM TIME TO TIME, NOT INTENDING TO, I imagine myself in charge of my own body. It's a faintly unpleasant sensation: sitting there in the cockpit, worrying whether everything is operational. The scariest part, easily, is the stomach.
docs.snippet: LEAD: FROM TIME TO TIME, NOT INTENDING TO, I imagine myself in charge of my own body. It's a faintly unpleasant sensation: sitting there in the cockpit, worrying whether everything is operational. The scariest part, easily, is the stomach.

byline.original: BY WILLIAM IRA BENNETT, M.D.: William Ira Bennett is the editor of The Harvard Medical School Health Letter

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: THE first patient in the United States to have human fetal cells implanted in his brain as a treatment for Parkinson's disease is showing small but steady improvement nearly six months after the surgery, his physician said yesterday.

headline.main: In Careful Test, Parkinson's Patient Shows Gains After Fetal-Cell Implant

docs.snippet: LEAD: THE first patient in the United States to have human fetal cells implanted in his brain as a treatment for Parkinson's disease is showing small but steady improvement nearly six months after the surgery, his physician said yesterday.
